div.p: Setting up a development environment is a crucial step for any developer. A well-configured environment enhances productivity and reduces errors. In this guide, we'll walk you through setting up a development environment on macOS using Visual Studio Code (VS Code), a popular and powerful code editor.

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (map glossref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

div.p: Before we begin, ensure you have the following:

ul.li: A Mac running macOS 10.15 (Catalina) or later.

li.span: In the Terminal, install Git using Homebrew:

li.span: Install Homebrew by pasting the following command and pressing Enter:

div.p: Visual Studio Code is a powerful and flexible code editor.

li.span: Download VS Code from the official website.
Open the downloaded file and drag VS Code to the Applications folder.
Launch VS Code from the Applications folder.

h1.span: Setting Up Python Environment in VS Code Topic File

h2.span: Setting Up a Python Environment in Visual Studio Code

div.p: Python is a popular programming language for various applications.

li.span: Open VS Code and install the Python extension:
Go to the Extensions view by clicking the square icon in the sidebar.
Search for "Python" and install the extension by Microsoft.
Open the Command Palette (Cmd+Shift+P) and type "Python: Select Interpreter".
